Just had a very good family day at CosmoCaixa Barcelona. Great value. This is state of the art stuff. I just can't understand the negativity in one or two other reviews. Yes I was a little confused on arrival as I have neither Spanish nor Catalan but when oriented after a while we spent 5 or 6 hours here today and found the staff great. Aside from the pretty amazing rainforest exhibit with live flora and fauna, the numerous 'experiments' illustrating some fundamentals about how the world works were wonderfully interactive and such fun for our kids. An amazing amount of money has been thrown at this and it really shows (must be a tax right-off for the Caixa Bank?). One nice touch is an outdoor picnic area for those who've brought their own food. We also used the cafeteria which is very good and found prices were reasonable - for Barcelona. Check this attraction out, especially if travelling with curious or intelligent children. A bus runs right by the museum, but afterwards we walked about 8 mins southwards downhill to catching to the Line 7 Metro at Tibidabo Station in Placa de John F Kennedy for a more direct route back to the Eixample.

Incredibly cheap museum for what they offer! For only 4 eur/person (free with Barcelona Card) we just loved the few hours (3-4) we spent here. The only regret was that we didn't have enough time to visit it entirely (5th floors) There was so much to do (interactive play), to see and to read....The tropical forest is awesome :)

Visited the museum to do something a little different and cheap during our visit in Barcelona. 

Getting the museum was easy, we got the metro and it's around a five minute walk away from the nearest station though slightly uphill so bear that in mind if you have a wheelchair or pram. 

The entrance fee is 4 euros which is really cheap and there are optional activities you can choose for additional costs - these looked really good for the kids.  

The museum is spread out over five floors though the majority of the exhibits are on the bottom floor. We were really impressed with the amount of hands on exhibits on this floor, there was absolutely loads to do and we spent around 2 hours on this floor alone - it was definitely educational! 

The rainforest is amazing - there's a glass wall between the main part of the bottom floor and the rainforest which means you can see the different animals swimming around - there's fish, stingrays, crocodile, turtles and capybara's! There's also a door which allows you to walk around and under the rainforest with various viewpoints. It was definitely the highlight of the visit! 

The only reason we did not give it five stars was that the layout initially is very confusing and trying to find the ticket office was a nightmare with the security and ticket barrier staff being less then helpful (please note: the exhibit staff were brilliant). Also, a couple of the exhibits weren't working. 

Tips
Factor in more money than just the Four euros for the entry fee - there are loads of additional extras that you can purchase such as hands on experience for the kids with animals and a 3D galaxy exhibit. The the additional activities, they do the majority of the them in English but only at certain times. If you want to do any I would definitely recommend pre-planning as there seemed to be only 1-2 a day of the English activities. 

Although brilliant for kids, it's also fun for adults. We are a 24 and 25 year old and we had a great time! 

There's a restaurant and picnic area for people planning on coming over lunch. 

We went on a weekday afternoon and it was really quiet. Quite a few school trips were leaving as we were arriving, so I would probably recommend going either early morning or after the schools have finished as I imagine that it can get busy and loud when there are school trips there.

I visited the museum in December. There was one other adult couple there and about 300 young school kids on a day trip! But they were mostly playing outside in the large garden area. 
I completely recommend this science museum for families or adults. Take a map so you can find  it, and its not that far from the metro.
The entry fee was such good value, it was something like €4.
You enter at the top level and wind your way down through the floors, each with a different theme, before emerging in the central 'rainforest' area (complete with animals, plants and rain!). 
It was cool and really interesting. There were lots of interactive parts and exhibits. I was surprised there were not more people there, maybe it is aimed more at school trips. There is a restaurant in the outdoor area.
